turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 161, Arthur Culombe versus -- Petitioner, versus Connecticut.
Mr. Goldfarb.

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Honorable Members of this Court, I am the special public defender appointed by the Superior Court of Hartford County one year after the trial of this case.
Petitioner, Your Honors please, is under sentence of death for the crime of murder in the first-degree on two counts, committed in the course of a robbery.
He seeks reversal of the judgement by a writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of Errors of the State of Connecticut which affirmed the conviction.

The petitioner is raising the issues in this case, involved the admission of three written confessions and one oral confession which were taken as follows, one on Wednesday, February 27th, five days after his apprehension and custody.

Another, Sunday, taken March 3rd, nine days after his apprehension and three days after he was formally charged with murder and third, the third one taken on Monday, March 4, 10 days after his apprehension and four days after he was formally charged with murder.
An oral confession was taken on Wednesday afternoon, February 27th, the day that he gave the first written confession, in the afternoon.
He gave the oral confession in the afternoon and the written confession late that evening or in the early morning hours of Thursday, February 28th.

We claim that these confessions, all of them, were coerced and involuntary and the latter two, namely the ones that were pro -- procured on Sunday and Monday were not only coerced and involuntary, but were procured in denial of counsel in violation of the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

The undisputed facts supporting these contentions are unequivocally and amply set forth in the record and are particularly outlined in our brief on a day-by-day analysis as stated in pages 4 through 17 of our brief.

It should be noted and it is very noteworthy that when the question of voluntariness is an issue in a court in the State of Connecticut, it is incumbent upon the State to prove that the confession was not involuntary.
In other words, the burden of proof is not upon the defendant to prove voluntariness, but upon the State to prove they were not involuntary.

I think it is well to consider, in considering all of the elements of coercion in this case and this case is a classic one, if I have ever saw one, Members of this Court, that we are dealing here essentially with a mental defective, a man who has the mentality of a nine to a nine and a half year old child with an IQ of 60, with the history of being confined in two state mental institutions, the Bridgewater State Hospital and the Wrentham State Hospital of Massachusetts when he was 17, a man who has been classified as a moron when he was 33 at the time of this crime and classified as an imbecile when he was 17, when he was first confined in the Bridgewater -- Bridgewater State Hospital.
A man whom the state psychiatrist conceded as a moron of a low grade or middle grade caliber and a man who, according to Bertram P.Ibelle, the clinical psychologist in this case, stated as follows.
All testing is consistent and indicative that this is clearly a feeble-minded individual, whose adjustment, both personal and social, could at best be marginal.
His performance is that of a middle grade moron and he can be properly labeled moderately defective.
In addition to being settled with deficient mental equipment with which he must try to cope with life's problems.
Mr. Culombe is also possessed of that character defect so frequently found in individuals of low intellectual caliber, namely he is enormously suggestible.
Thus, lacking in the capacity for sufficient critical judgment, his manner of thinking, his pattern of living and his way of behaving can all be easily influenced by those persons closest to him.
When the influences are benign, he gets along.
When the opposite obtains, he is in trouble.

In addition to the fact that we are dealing here with a feeble-minded individual, Arthur Culombe is an illiterate.
At the age of 16, he was still in the third grade.
He was in the third grade for a period of six years in the special class.
And he progressed no further than that.

His mother stated in testimony in this case that he was mental according to her -- the -- the pediatrician or the baby doctor, he was mental from the very beginning and I -- I recall, if I may, her statement, "But he was a child, because he used to have these crying spells, he couldn't sleep, then when he got older, he would stand up in his crib and scream and pull his hair and would go in a tantrum and throw himself on his stomach in the crib and I would call the doctor in the night and the doctor told me, he was mental.
He had a mental illness."
And this is at page 1211 of the record, if Your Honor pleases -- if Your Honors please.

In dealing here with a man of this type, we are now confronted with the various cause of conduct of the police in the handling of this case, which sets forth the situation of aggravated circumstance that reminds me of the Florida case, the Chambers versus Florida, the Fikes case, cases of lesser aggravated circumstance have been reversed by this Court.
And we have set forth these facts, beginning at page 4 of our brief.
First, Arthur Culombe was taken into custody, Saturday, February 23rd, at the State Police.
He was taken for a ride by three policemen through the County of Hartford and Coventry and Rocky Hill and various places around Hartford for purposes of identification.
After four or five hours of questioning in the car, he was returned to the State Police Barracks, State Police Headquarters.
There, he was further questioned.
Further, he was again taken back to his house where he was confronted with his wife and children.
And then he was sent back into the private car of the police where the Sergeant Paige talked with the -- with his wife while her husband was waiting outside to be carried back to the police barracks.

When he was returned to the police barracks that evening at 8 p.m., he was again questioned by -- by Lieutenant Rome, who was the chief protagonist, who was the leader of the -- of this group of mass relay questioners.
Lieutenant Rome questioned him further and at 10 o'clock that evening -- evening, placed him under arrest without a warrant, under our felony statute.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Well, (Inaudible) is not here and the jury is not (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Stated the -- the jury had actually passed in this case is not the plan to have (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: No, no.
We -- we did --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is it -- is it open to use by way of description so one can understand these things better humanly?
What does the -- what you mean by your remark that that becomes a great deal for the way in which the police examined?
You just said (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Well, that is the -- the gravamen of the crimes there.
You see, they were referred to as the mad dog killers in the press throughout the -- throughout the State.
And the public was aroused as evidenced by the mobs which had gathered outside of the New Britain courtroom, New Britain Police Station.
And the New Britain courtroom on Tuesday, which placed Arthur Culombe in tremendous fear, that matters he testified.
There were some references made that this is a lynch mob and -- and the people in New Britain were aroused by this because this is where the scenes of the two murders took place.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You finish -- you -- you covered Saturday, Mr. Goldfarb --

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- and you were interrupted by me and (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Sunday is a rather -- difficult to ascertain the particular times.
They are difficult to determine according to the transcript involved.
However, we do know the particular officers who did question the petitioner on that day.
He was questioned the afternoon by Sergent Paige for undeterminable period of time.
He was questioned also by Rome during that -- Lieutenant Rome, during the -- during that afternoon and by a Hartford detective during that afternoon.
And he was questioned again in the later part of the afternoon, the evening by Detective Paige.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: It was still on Saturday (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: This is on Sunday --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: On Sunday.

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: -- Mr Justice -- Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And what's the elapsed time?

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Approximately -- well, it was intermittently, we would say, for a period of two to three hours that he was questioned during that day.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that's the argument but beginning at what hour and ending at what hour?

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: The record doesn't indicate that sometime in the afternoon and evening.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: To -- to what this indeterminacy of -- of beginning and end or -- or duration?
To what witnesses were these time periods established?

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Through the police themselves?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Though the police themselves.

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Yes, the State --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And they weren't held down or perhaps that they couldn't remember the exact time.

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Yes.
And there were some confusion as to what days we were talking about in the course of the cross-examination by Attorney McDonough and Attorney Burke who represented the co-suspect.
Now, on Monday, petitioner, we claim, was questioned for a period at least, four to seven hours.
He was brought upstairs from his cell at State Police Headquarters and mind you, gentlemen, he is still confined at the State Police Barracks.
He has not been taken to any jail.
He's still under the influence and domination of the police.
At that day, he was promised counsel by Lieutenant Rome, promised counsel for his appearance in -- supposedly his appearance that day in some -- in -- in New Britain court.

But apparently, they did not get -- have time to take him to New Britain court that day because they were fingerprinting him all afternoon, taking pictures and photographs were being taken of him by reporters in New Britain at that time when he was finally taken to New Britain.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean, reporters are allowed into -- was this a police barracks?

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: It's -- this New Britain -- this is New Britain Police Station we're talking about now.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And the afternoon is spent in part in having photographs taken?

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Yes.
And the State Police admit that they had delayed in presenting him that day because they wanted further time to question him.
So they didn't present him until the following day, Tuesday, before the New Britain Police Court, which is a mockery of court procedure.
He was neither arraigned, he was not spoken to by the judge, he was placed in a cage at the rear of the police station on Tuesday -- of the court on Tuesday.
His vision was obscured, his hearing -- he was unable to hear what the judge had said.

And he wasn't -- there was no -- there was no formal complaint issued, so far as I understand, other than a breach of peace and technical charge of breach of the peace and he was placed on $25,000 bond.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, this was a preliminary hearing as it's called in some States or this was a committee magistrate?

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Committee magistrate, yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And then what's he do?
Bind him over to a grand jury?

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: He was -- was not bound over.
The case has continued for one week of that day.
He was held on a technical -- technical charge of breach of the peace at $25,000 bond and then --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What became -- he'd been arrested at 10 o'clock in the first day, quite in the wrong (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: He was -- he was arrested -- he was arrested with felony charge but felony charge was never prosecuted in the county.
They put him on -- placed him on a specious charge of breach of peace and he was to be held at $25,000 bond.
But more significantly, the Court issued a mittimus stating and directing that he'd be taken immediately forthwith to the Hartford County Jail and this mittimus is a matter of record here.
We pointed down as a matter of evidence, which this Court may review.
The mittimus directed that he'd be sent to the Hartford County Jail, which it was not done.
Instead of taking him to the Hartford County Jail, they took him back to State Police Barracks and questioned him further until that early evening for at least a period of eight hours.
And then --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Would you mind telling us -- would you mind telling us just what happened in that courtroom? What the surroundings were, what -- how many people in the courtroom, where he was and where the judge was?

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: The courtroom was mobbed with people.
He was placed in a -- an iron cage in the rear of the courtroom, he and the co-suspect.
His vision was obscured.
There were people standing in front of that cage.
He -- they're rumbling photographs and flashbulbs and television cameras, according to his statement were -- were talking pictures of him.
He was like a monkey in a cage.
And he was treated like an animal there and there was no -- he didn't hear what was going on.
There were some private conversation going on between the prosecutor and Lieutenant Rome and the other State Police.
And the judge, according to him, was mumbling some words, which he didn't understand what's going on.
And he -- he was completely inaudible to him and all he found out later on was that -- that he was being held on a breach of peace charge, technical charge of breach of peace at $25,000 bond.
And that's all that we know.
The record is not -- is specific as to issue --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Was there an issue of fact as to these conditions which you're describing or is that all conceded?

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Well, it's conceded there were mobs of people there.
It's conceded that some pictures were taken by the State.
They -- they had -- the State has admitted there were people there, meleeing all over the court.
And I -- I don't know whether or not, they are conceding that television cameras were there but they had certainly flashbulbs, a couple of flashbulbs, according to Lieutenant Rome.
He minimizes the effect of it -- of all of these but we -- we consider it a mockery of court procedure.
Certainly --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was it con -- conceded that he was in a cage in the back of the room --

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- and that there were innumerable people between him and the judge --

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: That is undisputed.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- while the so-called proceeding was going on?

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: That is undisputed, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was it portable?
I don't understand it.

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Portable cage (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: It was the usual cage where they confine prisoners who were recalcitrant, I assume.
I -- I don't know -- I don't think it's portable.
I think it's --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I think it's a piece of equipment common (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: I think it's a fixture of the -- of the premises.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Permanent cage?

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Yes, it's a permanent cage.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean all defendants, all defendants in capital basis?

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Pardon me.

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: I'm not familiar within the New Britain Police Court, Your Honor.
I practice law in the City of Hartford.
I've never practiced before the New Britain Police Court and I --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I think you have such a case in the Court.

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: There is a -- well, in -- in the Hartford Police Court, there is an adjoining room where one is confined.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I gather from what you describe, this is the cage in the courtroom, itself.

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: In the courtroom itself, yes.
There is in the Superior Court a bronze cage, a metal cage.
In the Superior Court, the Higher Court, where prisoners are confined, is called the pen, the prisoner's pen.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, when a trial proceeds, what is the length of trial of the court, Superior Court, isn't it?

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: The trial court here is the Superior Court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Superior Court.

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: This is a lower court, a minor court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I understand that.
What I want to know, whether it is the practice in Connecticut, in Hartford as part of Connecticut, that a defendant when the trial is on, sits -- is confined within the cage.

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: No, that is not the practice.
In fact, the -- the practices that the defendant appear at a table, to stand before a table, before the bench --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Would he -- would he --

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: -- that he not be separated from the bench by any sort of artificial means such as a cage as in this instance.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And he's near enough, his counsel so he can confer with him --

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Precisely.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- with perhaps a guard or two behind him.

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Yes, there was no counsel in this case provided him, nor were his constitutional rights, nor was he warned of his constitutional rights by the trial judge.
He didn't know what was going on.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is he -- was he in a cage during the trial period (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: No, he was not.
He was sitting with his counsel and myself in back of him.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: This proceeding that you're talking about really, technically, he, purportedly, had nothing to do with the murder prosecution as was on the breach of the peace.

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: No.
That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: And the case wasn't tried, as I understand (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: There was nothing that went -- that transpired, at least that he could hear.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: You're not saying to us that during some arraignment there, he was kept locked up in jail or in a cage.

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Well, I wouldn't call it an arraignment, Your Honor.
I would call it an -- an abortive presentment.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: And nothing happened with the (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Nothing transpired.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But was there -- after this proceeding in this Police Court, was there questioning shorty thereafter?

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Oh, yes, he was in -- he was removed from the Police Court, instead of being directed taken to the Hartford County Jail, where the mittimus directed that he be taken to forthwith, he was questioned for a period of eight hours.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: After the proceedings in this Police Court had ceased, is that it?

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So then I gather from the -- what you are putting before the Court is that the conditions under which he was appearing in that Police Court, in the context of what preceded and what followed, that -- that is relevant, has bearing upon the voluntariness of his confession.

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: Precisely.
Precisely, Your Honor.
This is one of the factors which -- this is one of the further evidences of the kind of police methods that were used in this case, the kind of police activity.

turn.speaker: alexander_a_goldfarb
turn.label: Mr. Alexander A. Goldfarb
turn.text: We'll recess now, Mr. Goldfard.
